did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Honey Lee Cottrell was a noted photographer who helped define lesbian erotica in the 1980s through her contributions to the women's sex magazine On Our Backs. She studied at the National Sex Forum and was a volunteer switchboard operator at San Francisco Sex Information. Her photographs appeared in I Am My Lover (1979), Coming to Power (1981), A Dyke's Bike Repair Handbook (1990), and Nothing But the Girl (1996), as well as in magazines including The Blatant Image and Sinister Wisdom. In 1981, Cottrell received a BA in film studies from San Francisco State University. She was director and camera for Sweet Dreams, starring Pat Califia (National Sex Forum, 1980), and from 1985 to the early 90s, a cinematographer for Fatale Video, the first lesbian-created erotic movie company. She photographed her lovers and friends and documented queer and kink cultures for decades with her first camera, a 35 mm Nikkormat.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Personal papers and photographic archives. Also, erotic and sex education videos of interest to lesbians and others by S.I.R. video production company, run by Shar Rednour and Jackie Strano, circa late 1980s, early 1990s. Shar and Jackie collaborated with Honey Lee to photograph and visualize projects. Honey Lee took photos of Shar for her book cover for The Femme's Ultimate Guide to the Universe. Photographs, event publicity, and files. Includes photos of Phyllis Christopher, friend and staff photographer for the periodical On Our Backs.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Honey Lee Cottrell Papers, #7822. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

altformavail.p: Digital scans of some photographs are also available through the digital portal.

did.unittitle: Interview of Honey Lee Cottrell by Brenda Marston

scopecontent.p: Description of full recording: On Sunday, September 6, 2015, Honey Lee Cottrell and Brenda Marston spent a few hours looking through Cottrell's files and photographs, which she is sending to be preserved in Cornell's Human Sexuality Collection. Cottrell explained the organization and highlights of the collection. A video camera was left on to record the conversation, which could contain helpful insight to those who later want to use the collection. At the end, Cottrell says "They need to be turned loose. I'm glad we're turning them loose on Cornell, but I'm like, man! You know, who's going to be lining up at Cornell to see these things?"

p.extref: An excerpt of the interview can be found here:

scopecontent.p: Description of Excerpt: September 6, 2015. Talking about her vision for the first issue of On Our Backs and the psycho-sexual subway map of urban lesbian life she created. Shows an ad for her erotic photography and reflects on the vision for both On Our Backs and Countervision. Highlights of her commentary as we look at the photographs and files she is sending to be preserved in Cornell's Human Sexuality Collection. (Talking with Brenda Marston.) 13:54 minutes.

Gayle, Marilyn What Lesbians Do, 1975 (inscribed and signed by the author and artist Barbary)
